pr_title: Parquet: Right trim char types during insert

timeline.message:
Parquet: Right trim char types during insert

Currently, there is an issue when inserting parquet data with char types
when they are padded. For example,

    CREATE WRITABLE EXTERNAL TABLE foo (id int, code char(5))
    LOCATION ('pxf://bucket/path?PROFILE=s3:parquet&SERVER=s3')
    FORMAT 'CUSTOM' (formatter='pxfwritable_export');

    INSERT INTO foo VALUE (1, '95126'), (2, '9'), (3, '9');

This will cause postgres to right pad tuples 2 and 3 with whitespace
after the char '9', which will be sent to PXF Server as '9    ', and
we'll store it as such in a parquet file. However, this is inconsistent
with Hive's behavior and it is also causing issues with predicate
pushdown. Queries like the following will produce no tuples:

    SELECT * FROM foo WHERE code = '9';

With this patch, we right-trim values of type char coming from Greenplum
before storing them to parquet. This brings us on-par with the way Hive
stores char types and it fixes predicate pushdown.

timeline.message:
Parquet: Transform char predicates with trailing whitespace

When a predicate for a char type has trailing whitespace we transform
the query to c1 = 'a  ' to (c1 = 'a  ' OR c1 = 'a'). This allows us to
push the original predicate, but also it provides consistency with the
way we are storing char types in parquet. When the operator is a not
equals the query is transformed from c1 <> 'a  ' to (c1 <> 'a  ' AND c1
<> 'a').

Renamed the SupportedParquetPrimitiveTypePruner class to
ParquetOperatorPrunerAndTransformer to take into account the new
functionality of the class.
